name: Alayna McCann
comment info:
Frog eye salad is a sweet, creamy dessert or side dish made with tiny, round acini di pepe pasta, canned fruits (typically pineapple and mandarin oranges), whipped topping, and often mini marshmallows and shredded. An easy, no-bake dirt pudding (or "dirt cake") can be made quickly using instant pudding mix, whipped topping, and crushed Oreo cookies. 
Ingredients.An easy and popular recipe for sopapilla cheesecake bars uses refrigerated crescent roll dough to create a layered dessert with a creamy, cinnamon-sugar topping. It is a simple, no-fuss recipe perfect for a potluck or easy dessert. 
Sopapilla Cheesecake Bars Recipe. and these are the 3 I wanted to know about. (FROG EYE SALAD, DIRT PUDDING, AND SOPAOLLA CHEESECAKE.

name: Anonymous P Block 1
comment info:
Looking at this graph, I can see all the state's favorite Thanksgiving side dishes. I can see how these traditional side dishes vary. I find it interesting that there are so many different food favorites in different states. I had never heard of cookie salad or pig pickin cake, nor frog eye salad. 

I wonder why some of these meals are so obscure, like the frog eye salad. That's pasta, pineapple, coconut and mandarin oranges? Topped with cream? I mean, that seems a little strange. But it's not my state, so I don’t know. 

Where I am from, NC, it's usually just mashed potatoes and green bean casserole. I’ve never even had pig pickin cake. 
My favorite side dishes have always been the same, to be honest. Buttery, creamed mashed potatoes and homemade baked mac and cheese. Those two things with a big turkey slice are the best on thanksgiving. I also adore pecan pie, it's heavenly with a scoop of French vanilla ice cream.

name: emery s
comment info: Looking at this graph taken from a TheUpshot article, you can see the mundane cultural differences in people’s favorite side dishes. Arizona residents add an ethnic twist to the classic turkey dish, with the most popular side being turkey enchiladas. There’s also aspects in these favored dishes that just show the agricultural traits of states, for example California’s San Joaquin Valley produces loads of yams as a popular organic ‘superfood’, with which state’s residents use to make persimmon bread. I don’t know how I’ve never heard of any of these dishes or foods, and honestly I’ve never heard of the favored dish in my own state. “Pig pickin’ cake”, North Carolina’s apparent favorite, is a fruity dessert that came from pig barbecues in the south. There’s yellow cake, mandarin, oranges and whipped cream to fill in the layers and topped with pecans as well as vanilla pudding. When I hear about this dessert I think of my grandma, who’s totally an old jello and circus peanut salad fashioned kind of woman, but I guess she just stuck with the ambrosia salad over the orange nutty cake with time.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info:
@emery s
I like how you described cultural differences between state dishes. I also had never heard of pig pickin cake until now. I find it fascinating how different each states favorite side dish is, mine are usually just mashed potatoes and pecan pie. I also like how you referred to your grandma with NC's favorite dessert, which I have also never had. I appreciate you explaining what pig pickin cake is, and I really like your voice in this.

name: Anuradha
comment info:
What do you notice? 
I notice that pies are very popular in the New England states. For instance, pumpkin woopie pie is enjoyed in both Maine and Vermont, Maple Walnut Pie is a favorite in New Hampshire, and chocolate cream pie is a popular dish in Rhode Island. In addition, I notice that both New Mexico and Florida’s most popular dishes seem to have Hispanic influence. Lastly, I notice that Frog Eye Salad is a favorite dish in the Far West states of Montana, Wyoming, Idaho, Colorado, and Nevada. 

What do you wonder?

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Deniol Billa Great answer! In response to your point about different regions sharing one type of food: I think the most prominent types of food are most probably related to the culture and way of life in their regions. For example, in the 1900s, the Northeast was home to cities, factories, and retail workers. City life moves fast, so salads (a food that can be eaten quickly) might reflect the fast-paced city life. The southeast is also known for its large families. Casseroles are typically dishes that can be shared between many people. I infer that this might be the reason why the southeast's favorite Thanksgiving foods contain a lot of casseroles.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s map shows the “most distinct” Thanksgiving side dishes by state based on the number of Google recipe searches for the week before Thanksgiving for the period 2004 -2013.  By SELECTING THE STATE from the article (link in the release), you will see how much more distinct, on a per capita basis, this side dish and other dishes are in this state versus the rest of the country.  For example, in Colorado, frog eye salad is 14 times more commonly searched (relative to population size) than in the rest of the country.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you?”

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in the map. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included this map and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”
